natural problem:
What is the equation of the oblique asymptote of the graph of $\frac{2x^2+x-13}{2x-5}$?

Enter your answer in the form $y = mx + b.$
natural solution: \multicolumn{2}{r}{} & 6x & -15 \\ \cline{3-4} \multicolumn{2}{r}{} & 0 &+  2 \\ \end{array} \]Hence, we can write $$\frac{2x^2+x-13}{2x-5} = x + 3 + \frac{2}{2x-5}.$$So we can see that as $x$ becomes far from $0$, the graph of the function gets closer and closer to the line $\boxed{y = x+3}.$

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x y m b :: real and P Q R :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = (2 * x powr 2 + x - 13) / (2 * x - 5)"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. Q x = m * x + b"
and h2 : "x \<noteq> 5 / 2"
and h3 : "P x - Q x = R x"
and h4 : "R x \<longrightarrow>\<^sub>L 0"
shows  "m = 1" and "b = 3"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the equation of the oblique asymptote of the graph of $\frac{2x^2+x-13}{2x-5}$?

Enter your answer in the form $y = mx + b.$ The final Answer is y = x+3
 ### Proof
 Polynomial long division gives us \[ \begin{array}{c|ccc} \multicolumn{2}{r}{x} & +3 \\ \cline{2-4} 2x-5 & 2x^2&+x&-13 \\ \multicolumn{2}{r}{2x^2} & -5x &   \\ \cline{2-3} \multicolumn{2}{r}{0} & 6x &  -13 \\
 \multicolumn{2}{r}{} & 6x & -15 \\ \cline{3-4} \multicolumn{2}{r}{} & 0 &+  2 \\ \end{array} \]Hence, we can write $$\frac{2x^2+x-13}{2x-5} = x + 3 + \frac{2}{2x-5}.$$So we can see that as $x$ becomes far from $0$, the graph of the function gets closer and closer to the line $\boxed{y = x+3}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes x y m b :: real and P Q R :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = (2 * x powr 2 + x - 13) / (2 * x - 5)"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. Q x = m * x + b"
and h2 : "x \<noteq> 5 / 2"
and h3 : "P x - Q x = R x"
and h4 : "R x \<longrightarrow>\<^sub>L 0"
shows  "m = 1" and "b = 3"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Consider two functions $P(x)$ and $Q(x)$. $P(x)$ is defined as $(2x^2 + x - 13) / (2x - 5)$ and $Q(x)$ is defined as $mx + b$. Additionally, there is a function $R(x)$ which is equal to $P(x) - Q(x)$ and $R(x)$ is strictly decreasing. If $x \neq 5/2$, find the values of $m$ and $b$. The final answer is $m = 1$ and $b = 3$.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x y :: real and f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real" and g :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = (2 * x powr 2 + x - 13) / (2 * x - 5)"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. g x = x + 3"
and h2 : "y = f x"
shows  "y = g x"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the equation of the oblique asymptote of the graph of $\frac{2x^2+x-13}{2x-5}$?

Enter your answer in the form $y = mx + b.$ The final Answer is y = x+3
 ### Proof
 Polynomial long division gives us \[ \begin{array}{c|ccc} \multicolumn{2}{r}{x} & +3 \\ \cline{2-4} 2x-5 & 2x^2&+x&-13 \\ \multicolumn{2}{r}{2x^2} & -5x &   \\ \cline{2-3} \multicolumn{2}{r}{0} & 6x &  -13 \\
 \multicolumn{2}{r}{} & 6x & -15 \\ \cline{3-4} \multicolumn{2}{r}{} & 0 &+  2 \\ \end{array} \]Hence, we can write $$\frac{2x^2+x-13}{2x-5} = x + 3 + \frac{2}{2x-5}.$$So we can see that as $x$ becomes far from $0$, the graph of the function gets closer and closer to the line $\boxed{y = x+3}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes x y :: real and f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real" and g :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = (2 * x powr 2 + x - 13) / (2 * x - 5)"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. g x = x + 3"
and h2 : "y = f x"
shows  "y = g x"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Given two functions $f$ and $g$ where $f(x) = \frac{2x^2 + x - 13}{2x - 5}$ and $g(x) = x + 3$. For some real number $x$, if $y$ equals to $f(x)$, then prove that $y$ also equals to $g(x)$.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: real and P Q R :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = (2 * x powr 2 + x - 13) / (2 * x - 5)"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. Q x = x"
and h2 : "\<forall> x. R x = 3"
and h3 : "\<forall> x. P x - Q x - R x = 0"
shows  "\<forall> x. P x = Q x + R x"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the equation of the oblique asymptote of the graph of $\frac{2x^2+x-13}{2x-5}$?

Enter your answer in the form $y = mx + b.$ The final Answer is y = x+3
 ### Proof
 Polynomial long division gives us \[ \begin{array}{c|ccc} \multicolumn{2}{r}{x} & +3 \\ \cline{2-4} 2x-5 & 2x^2&+x&-13 \\ \multicolumn{2}{r}{2x^2} & -5x &   \\ \cline{2-3} \multicolumn{2}{r}{0} & 6x &  -13 \\
 \multicolumn{2}{r}{} & 6x & -15 \\ \cline{3-4} \multicolumn{2}{r}{} & 0 &+  2 \\ \end{array} \]Hence, we can write $$\frac{2x^2+x-13}{2x-5} = x + 3 + \frac{2}{2x-5}.$$So we can see that as $x$ becomes far from $0$, the graph of the function gets closer and closer to the line $\boxed{y = x+3}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes x :: real and P Q R :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = (2 * x powr 2 + x - 13) / (2 * x - 5)"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. Q x = x"
and h2 : "\<forall> x. R x = 3"
and h3 : "\<forall> x. P x - Q x - R x = 0"
shows  "\<forall> x. P x = Q x + R x"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: If $P(x) = \frac{2x^2 + x - 13}{2x - 5}$, $Q(x) = x$, and $R(x) = 3$, find a value for $x$ such that $P(x) = Q(x) + R(x)$.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x y m b :: real and f g h :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = 2 * x powr 2 + x - 13"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. g x = 2 * x - 5"
and h2 : "\<forall> x. h x = f x / g x"
and h3 : "\<forall> x. lim (h x) x = m * x + b"
shows  "m = 1 \<and> b = 3"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the equation of the oblique asymptote of the graph of $\frac{2x^2+x-13}{2x-5}$?

Enter your answer in the form $y = mx + b.$ The final Answer is y = x+3
 ### Proof
 Polynomial long division gives us \[ \begin{array}{c|ccc} \multicolumn{2}{r}{x} & +3 \\ \cline{2-4} 2x-5 & 2x^2&+x&-13 \\ \multicolumn{2}{r}{2x^2} & -5x &   \\ \cline{2-3} \multicolumn{2}{r}{0} & 6x &  -13 \\
 \multicolumn{2}{r}{} & 6x & -15 \\ \cline{3-4} \multicolumn{2}{r}{} & 0 &+  2 \\ \end{array} \]Hence, we can write $$\frac{2x^2+x-13}{2x-5} = x + 3 + \frac{2}{2x-5}.$$So we can see that as $x$ becomes far from $0$, the graph of the function gets closer and closer to the line $\boxed{y = x+3}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes x y m b :: real and f g h :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = 2 * x powr 2 + x - 13"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. g x = 2 * x - 5"
and h2 : "\<forall> x. h x = f x / g x"
and h3 : "\<forall> x. lim (h x) x = m * x + b"
shows  "m = 1 \<and> b = 3"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: Find the slope and y-intercept of the line that represents the limit as x approaches infinity for the function $h(x) = \frac{f(x)}{g(x)}$ where $f(x) = 2x^2 + x - 13$ and $g(x) = 2x - 5$. The final answer is that the slope is $1$ and the y-intercept is $3$.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x y :: real and f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = (2 * x powr 2 + x - 13) / (2 * x - 5)"
and h1 : "\<exists> m b. \<forall> x. y = m * x + b"
shows  "y = x + 3"

 *)

theorem
fixes x y :: real and f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = (2 * x powr 2 + x - 13) / (2 * x - 5)"
and h1 : "\<exists> m b. \<forall> x. y = m * x + b"
shows  "y = x + 3"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: Given a function $f$ defined by $f(x) = \frac{2x^2 + x - 13}{2x - 5}$, find a linear equation in the form $y=mx+b$ that holds true for all $x$. The final answer is $y = x + 3$.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: real and f g :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = (2 * x powr 2 + x - 13) / (2 * x - 5)"
and h1 : "x \<noteq> 2.5"
shows  "f(x) \<sim> g(x)"

shows  "f(x) \<sim> g(x)"
where "g x = x + 3"

fixes x y m b :: real and f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"

shows  "m = 1 \<and> b = 3"

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x y :: real and f g :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = (2 * x powr 2 + x - 13) / (2 * x - 5)"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. g x = x + 3"
and h2 : "\<forall> x. x \<noteq> 5/2 \<longrightarrow> ((f x - g x) / x) tends to 0 at_top"
shows  "\<forall> x. y = g x"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the equation of the oblique asymptote of the graph of $\frac{2x^2+x-13}{2x-5}$?

Enter your answer in the form $y = mx + b.$ The final Answer is y = x+3
 ### Proof
 Polynomial long division gives us \[ \begin{array}{c|ccc} \multicolumn{2}{r}{x} & +3 \\ \cline{2-4} 2x-5 & 2x^2&+x&-13 \\ \multicolumn{2}{r}{2x^2} & -5x &   \\ \cline{2-3} \multicolumn{2}{r}{0} & 6x &  -13 \\
 \multicolumn{2}{r}{} & 6x & -15 \\ \cline{3-4} \multicolumn{2}{r}{} & 0 &+  2 \\ \end{array} \]Hence, we can write $$\frac{2x^2+x-13}{2x-5} = x + 3 + \frac{2}{2x-5}.$$So we can see that as $x$ becomes far from $0$, the graph of the function gets closer and closer to the line $\boxed{y = x+3}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes x y :: real and f g :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = (2 * x powr 2 + x - 13) / (2 * x - 5)"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. g x = x + 3"
and h2 : "\<forall> x. x \<noteq> 5/2 \<longrightarrow> ((f x - g x) / x) tends to 0 at_top"
shows  "\<forall> x. y = g x"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: Consider two functions, $f(x)$ and $g(x)$, where $f(x) = \frac{2x^2 + x - 13}{2x - 5}$ and $g(x) = x + 3$. If the limit of $\frac{f(x) - g(x)}{x}$ as $x$ approaches infinity is $0$, and $x$ is not equal to $\frac{5}{2}$, then for all $x$, $y$ equals $g(x)$.

theorem
fixes x y :: real

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x y m b :: real and P Q :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = 2 * x powr 2 + x - 13"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. Q x = 2 * x - 5"
and h2 : "\<exists> m b. \<forall> x. P x / Q x = m * x + b"
shows  "\<exists> m b. m = 1 \<and> b = 3"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the equation of the oblique asymptote of the graph of $\frac{2x^2+x-13}{2x-5}$?

Enter your answer in the form $y = mx + b.$ The final Answer is y = x+3
 ### Proof
 Polynomial long division gives us \[ \begin{array}{c|ccc} \multicolumn{2}{r}{x} & +3 \\ \cline{2-4} 2x-5 & 2x^2&+x&-13 \\ \multicolumn{2}{r}{2x^2} & -5x &   \\ \cline{2-3} \multicolumn{2}{r}{0} & 6x &  -13 \\
 \multicolumn{2}{r}{} & 6x & -15 \\ \cline{3-4} \multicolumn{2}{r}{} & 0 &+  2 \\ \end{array} \]Hence, we can write $$\frac{2x^2+x-13}{2x-5} = x + 3 + \frac{2}{2x-5}.$$So we can see that as $x$ becomes far from $0$, the graph of the function gets closer and closer to the line $\boxed{y = x+3}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes x y m b :: real and P Q :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = 2 * x powr 2 + x - 13"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. Q x = 2 * x - 5"
and h2 : "\<exists> m b. \<forall> x. P x / Q x = m * x + b"
shows  "\<exists> m b. m = 1 \<and> b = 3"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Given two functions $P(x) = 2x^2 + x - 13$ and $Q(x) = 2x - 5$, there exists constants $m$ and $b$ such that the ratio of $P(x)$ to $Q(x)$ is a linear function in the form $mx + b$. Find the values of $m$ and $b$. The final answer is $m = 1$ and $b = 3$.
